items.title: Swiss bar missed years of fire safety inspections before deadly blaze
items.description: Swiss authorities admitted that fire safety inspections hadn't been carried out since 2019 at Crans-Montana bar where 40 people died on New Year's Eve.

items.title: US set to back Ukrainian defence coalition if peace deal made with Russia
items.description: A draft statement outlines what Ukraine's allies could commit to if Russia attacks its neighbour again in the future.

items.title: Boston Dynamics unveils Atlas robot, partners with Google DeepMind

featured_image.name: Hyundai Motor Group To Accelerate Human–Robot Collaboration in ...

items.description:
Boston Dynamics publicly demonstrated its Atlas humanoid robot for the first time on Monday at CES 2026 in Las Vegas, marking a milestone in the company's decades-long effort to bring industrial robots from laboratory prototypes to factory floors[1][2][3][4].

"For the first time ever in public, please welcome Atlas to the stage," said Zachary Jackowski, Boston Dynamics' vice president and general manager for humanoid robots, as the 5-foot-9, 200-pound machine rose from the floor of a Las Vegas hotel ballroom[1][3][4]. The robot walked fluidly across the stage for several minutes, waving to the crowd and swiveling its head in owl-like motions[1][3][4].

items.title: UN condemns US military operation in Venezuela

featured_image.name: At the U.N., Even Allies Condemn U.S. Action in Venezuela

items.description:
The United Nations Human Rights Office issued a sharp rebuke Tuesday of the US military operation in Venezuela, warning that the intervention undermines international law and makes "all states less safe around the world."[1][2][3][4]

Speaking at a media briefing in Geneva, Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Turk, said the operation "violated a fundamental principle of international law" that prohibits states from using force against the territorial integrity or political independence of another state.[1][5][2] "It sends a signal that the powerful can do whatever they like," Shamdasani told reporters.[2][4][6]

The criticism follows the January 3 US military strike on Venezuela that resulted in the capture of President Nicolas Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores. More than 150 US aircraft bombed military installations across Caracas in the predawn operation, codenamed "Absolute Resolve," before special forces extracted Maduro from the Venezuelan capital.[7][8] Venezuelan officials reported at least 80 people were killed, including civilians.[8]

items.title: Nvidia, AMD, Intel unveil AI chips at CES 2026

featured_image.name: Watch the NVIDIA CES 2026 keynote with CEO Jensen Huang live here: AI, robotics updates and more

items.description:
The opening day of CES 2026 delivered a cascade of artificial intelligence and semiconductor announcements as industry giants Nvidia, AMD, and Intel unveiled new chips and AI platforms targeting everything from data centers to laptops.

In keynote presentations on Monday, January 5—a day before CES officially opened its doors—the three chipmakers outlined their visions for what Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang called "physical AI," signaling a shift from cloud-based systems to AI that powers robots, autonomous vehicles, and everyday devices.

items.title: Nikkei 225 closes at record high in historic Asian rally

featured_image.name: AI Bubble Fears and Policy Splits Loom Over Asia Stocks in 2026

items.description:
Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 closed at a record high on Tuesday, capping a historic opening to 2026 for Asian equities as investors pivoted away from U.S. markets toward regional tech stocks and AI-related investments[1][2].

The Nikkei 225 gained 1.3% to close at 52,518.08, surpassing its previous record set on October 31[1][3]. The rally was led by technology-related shares, including precision tools maker Disco Corp., which surged 6.1%[1]. The broader TOPIX index also reached an all-time high[4][5].

items.title: NASA's Artemis II to roll out to launch pad within two weeks

featured_image.name: Artemis II rollout 'less than two weeks away,' launch window opens ...

items.description:
NASA announced Friday that its Artemis II mission is less than two weeks away from rolling out to the launch pad, marking the first step toward returning astronauts to lunar orbit after more than five decades[1]. The announcement signals the beginning of what industry observers are calling an unprecedented year for moon missions, with at least five commercial lunar landers also targeting 2026 launches alongside NASA's flagship program[2].

NASA Press Secretary Bethany Stevens confirmed that the agency's Space Launch System rocket will move to the launch pad by mid-January, with a launch window opening February 6 and extending through April[1][3]. The mission will send four astronauts—NASA's Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, and Christina Koch, along with the Canadian Space Agency's Jeremy Hansen—on a roughly 10-day journey around the moon[4][5]. It will mark the first time humans have traveled beyond low-Earth orbit since Apollo 17 in 1972[5][6].

items.title: Clark denies confrontation with CA boss after interview ban
items.description: Stuart Clark opens up on his conversation with Cricket Australia chief Todd Greenberg after his stinging criticism.

items.title: What are Nicolás Maduro and Cilia Flores alleged to have done?
items.description: The US has justified the seizure of deposed Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro and wife Cilia Flores by arguing they had breached US domestic law. So what exactly have they been accused of doing?

items.title: AMD unveils AI chips, gaming processors at CES

featured_image.name: AMD shows off new higher performing AI chip at CES event

items.description:
AMD CEO Lisa Su took the stage at CES 2026 in Las Vegas on January 5, unveiling a comprehensive lineup of processors spanning data centers, consumer PCs, embedded systems, and gaming, as the chipmaker intensifies its competition with rival Nvidia in the AI computing market.

The announcements included the Ryzen 7 9850X3D desktop gaming processor, new AI-powered laptop and desktop chips, advanced data center accelerators, and embedded processors designed for automotive and industrial applications[1][2][3]. OpenAI president Greg Brockman joined Su on stage to discuss the companies' partnership, which was announced in October 2025[4][5].

items.title: Smith treats Sydney to a Smudge Day, in all its weird and wonderful glory
items.description: Steve Smith was at his bizarre best on day three in Sydney, grinding England into the dust with his scintillating strokeplay and trademark oddness.

items.title: Nvidia unveils Rubin AI platform, robotaxi pilot

featured_image.name: 3 major takeaways from Nvidia Live at CES 2026

items.description:
Nvidia used its CES 2026 keynote in Las Vegas to argue that the next phase of artificial intelligence will be built less around chatbots and more around machines that can perceive, reason and act in the real world—while the company supplies the underlying compute stack.[1][2][3]

The presentation came after Nvidia’s historic run in 2025, when it became the first publicly traded company to top a $5 trillion market capitalization.[4][5][6] By early January 2026, its valuation had slipped back to roughly the mid-$4 trillion range, underscoring how quickly the numbers can swing even for the market’s biggest AI beneficiary.[7][8][9]

items.title: Nvidia, AMD unveil AI and gaming chips at CES

featured_image.name: Watch the CES 2026 Nvidia keynote livestream now

items.description:
Nvidia and AMD kicked off CES 2026 with major chip announcements on Monday, as the chipmakers battle for dominance in the booming artificial intelligence and gaming markets. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang confirmed its next-generation Vera Rubin AI platform is already in full production, while AMD CEO Lisa Su unveiled new processors spanning gaming, mobile, and embedded AI applications[1][2][3].

Huang announced that Vera Rubin, the successor to Nvidia's Blackwell architecture, delivers five times the AI inference performance of its predecessor while using a quarter of the GPUs for training complex AI models[1][4][5]. The platform comprises six integrated chips—including the Vera CPU and Rubin GPU—and is slated for deployment in the second half of 2026[1][6]. According to Nvidia, major cloud providers including Amazon, Microsoft, and Google have already committed to adopting the platform[1][3].

items.title: Calls for a royal commission into Bondi an untenable political distraction
items.description: Whether or not Anthony Albanese believes a federal royal commission is necessary, or even the best use of resources, is now politically irrelevant.

items.title: 'It wasn't your fault': Ben Austin's parents offer support for other boy involved in cricket tragedy
items.description: Ben Austin died after a cricket ball struck him in late October. For the first time his parents speak exclusively about the incident and their belief no one is to blame for the tragic accident.

items.title: Asian stocks hit record highs on tech, chip gains

featured_image.name: Asian stocks set for strongest annual jump in eight years on ...

items.description:
Asian stock markets surged to fresh record highs on Tuesday, powered by technology and semiconductor shares as investors continued to bet on surging artificial intelligence demand, while oil prices steadied following a brief spike over geopolitical tensions.

The MSCI Asia-Pacific index climbed 0.4% to its highest level on record, marking a fourth consecutive day of gains[1][2][3]. Japan's TOPIX index jumped 1.3% to a record peak, while the Nikkei 225 hovered near record levels with a 0.7% gain[4][5][2]. Hong Kong's Hang Seng advanced between 0.7% and 1.2%, with the Hang Seng TECH sub-index climbing nearly 2%[4][5][3].

items.title: 'It's going down': Trump names four places he could hit next
items.description: Donald Trump is talking about where US forces might venture next. But one of his cabinet secretaries could provide the clearest clues.

items.title: PM doesn't rule out royal commission into Bondi terror attack
items.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese does not rule out calling a royal commission into the Bondi Beach terrorist attack, but says his immediate priority is the review of intelligence and security agencies.

items.title: Nvidia, Hyundai, Intel unveil AI chips and robots at CES

featured_image.name: Nvidia CEO Huang touts automotive AI at CES talk as competition mounts

items.description:
The world's leading technology companies converged on Las Vegas Monday to showcase groundbreaking artificial intelligence innovations at the Consumer Electronics Show, with Nvidia, Hyundai, and Intel each debuting major new products aimed at advancing AI capabilities across data centers, factories, and personal computers.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang opened CES with the announcement of the Vera Rubin AI platform, the company's next-generation chip architecture that promises to deliver five times the artificial intelligence inference performance and 3.5 times the training performance of its current Blackwell chips[1][2][3][4]. The platform, comprising six integrated chips including the Rubin GPU with 336 billion transistors and 288GB of HBM4 memory, is expected to become available through partners in the second half of 2026[1][2][4].

"The timing of Rubin's launch is perfect, as the demand for AI computing, both for training and inference, is skyrocketing," Huang said during his keynote[2]. The announcement comes as Nvidia faces intensifying competition from rivals including Advanced Micro Devices and customers like Alphabet's Google developing their own AI chips[5].

items.title: Venezuela is a 'powder keg' after US attack. Here's what could come next
items.description: The US capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro left the country with an uncertain future, sparked concern among regional neighbours and could embolden other countries in territorial disputes, some experts say.
